topic.description: Should Governments Ever Limit Free Speech?

userTurns.utterance: As the founder of a free society is aptly concerned that "Were Liberty Forbidden all Freedom Could" so should it make one ponder, should governments balance liberties at certain boundaries for order with the liberties they secure?

systemResponse.utterance: Governments must constantly balance individual liberties with collective safety and order. While true liberty implies minimal interference, it must also be protected from those who would infringe upon the rights of others. Therefore, some authority is necessary to delineate boundaries of liberty to prevent chaos and ensure the security of all citizens.

response.content: Governments must constantly balance individual liberties with collective safety and order. While true liberty implies minimal interference, it must also be protected from those who would infringe upon the rights of others. Therefore, some authority is necessary to delineate boundaries of liberty to prevent chaos and ensure the security of all citizens.

arguments.topic: The Libertarian Solution: Can People Govern Themselves?
arguments.attacks: The intended role of the government is social intervention, not protection.
arguments.supports: The intended role of the government is protection, not social intervention.
arguments.text: "The only maxim of a free government ought to be to trust no man living with the power to endanger the public liberty" John Adams. So government wasn't intended by the founding fathers to control the citizen nor the public but to control powers that threaten them. In theory, it would mean government only needs enough power to perform that basic task, and the more limited societal powers are the more limited government powers could be.

arguments.topic: Should short-term apartment leasing services such as Airbnb be prohibited in New York City?
arguments.attacks: While the social contract is absolute and necessarily demands punitive measures on individuals.
arguments.supports: While the social contract is useful in so far as it guarantees bodily safety for individuals, and would therefore be irrational to eschew entirely, it is not absolute nor does it necessarily demand such punitive measures on individuals.
arguments.text: While it is at the discretion of the government to decide what liberties to trade off in favour of protections, that does not mean that what they decide is necessarily what ought to be done.

arguments.topic: Should Governments Ever Limit Free Speech?
arguments.attacks: Free speech is not a fundamental human right.
arguments.supports: Free speech is a fundamental human right.
arguments.text: Freedom is absolute or it's not freedom at all. Any limitation on freedom of speech automatically violates the idea itself. As Benjamin Franklin said: "Any society that would give up a little liberty to gain a little security will deserve neither and lose both."

arguments.topic: Is It Ever Right to Take Away Someone's Choice?
arguments.attacks: Taking away someone's right to choose assumes that what is good for them (their utility function) is the same as yours or follows some external standard. However, the best evidence of someone's utility function is what they choose to do (assuming they are of sound mind, etc.).
arguments.supports: Not taking away someone's right to choose does not assume that what is good for them is the same as yours or follows some external standard.
arguments.text: Not necessarily. One need not consider what is good for the subject at all in order to limit their freedom. In some cases, the potential harm involved in allowing a person to act freely can justify limiting their actions.

arguments.topic: Should high-income countries take in refugees?
arguments.attacks: Conservative conceptions of justice are not skeptical of untempered democratic mandate, and nations should do what has the most popular support.
arguments.supports: Conservative conceptions of justice are also skeptical of untempered democratic mandate. Nations should do what is right, not necessarily what has the most popular support.
arguments.text: "Real liberty is neither found in despotism or the extremes of democracy, but in moderate governments."-Alexander Hamilton, debate on the floor of the Constitutional Convention, 26 Jun 1787.

arguments.topic: Should There be a Universal Basic Income (UBI)?
arguments.attacks: Aside from a minarchist system there is no form of governance where no negative rights are infringed. There can be no individual liberty when people are forced by the government to transfer money to others (coercive redistribution).
arguments.supports: Aside from a minarchist system there is no form of governance where no negative rights are infringed is not true.
arguments.text: Individual liberty must be protected by some organization at some expense, as there are many individuals who would otherwise be willing to infringe others' rights for their own benefit. Therefore, some form of government is necessary and essential for protecting individuals' rights.

arguments.topic: Should US intelligence agencies end mass data collection?
arguments.attacks: Governments always have to balance civil liberties with the safety interests of their citizens.
arguments.supports: Governments never have to balance civil liberties with the safety interests of their citizens.
arguments.text: If the US government cared about balancing civil liberties with the safety interests of its citizens, then it would have banned the purchasing of firearms. More people have died due to gun related violence, than as a result of terrorism. Therefore the government has no moral grounds to decide which civil liberties should or should not be compromised for the purpose of security.

userTurns.utterance: To be straightforward, I think pineapple does belong on pizza, adding a unique and flavorful sweetness to an already versatile dish for diverse culinary experiences and preferences.

systemResponse.utterance: While you see pineapple's sweetness as an enhancement, mixing fruit with savory ingredients disrupts the traditional flavor harmony of pizza. The sweet, juicy notes of pineapple detract from the established savory profile, creating a clash that disappoints those accustomed to pizza as a purely savory experience.

response.content: While you see pineapple's sweetness as an enhancement, mixing fruit with savory ingredients disrupts the traditional flavor harmony of pizza. The sweet, juicy notes of pineapple detract from the established savory profile, creating a clash that disappoints those accustomed to pizza as a purely savory experience.

arguments.attacks: Pineapple provides aesthetic tastes and taste experiences.
arguments.supports: Pineapple does not provide aesthetic tastes and taste experiences.
arguments.text: When people decide to put pineapple on pizza, they end up compromising its original, traditional savory taste, like pizza, with non-complementary sweet and fruity notes.

arguments.attacks: The sweetness of the pineapple is a bad fit for the general taste of the pizza.
arguments.supports: The sweetness of the pineapple is a good fit for the general taste of the pizza.
arguments.text: As long as the ingredients are fresh and the pizza is well-made, there's no reason why the sweetness of the pineapple would be a bad fit for the general taste of pizza.

arguments.attacks: Pineapple does not synergistically complement other toppings to make pizza overall taste better.
arguments.supports: Pineapple synergistically complements other toppings to make pizza overall taste better.
arguments.text: Chefs typically balance sweet, sour, salty, umami and bitter flavours in a dish. Pineapple is primarily sweet with some sourness. Hence, it is perfectly valid as a sweet pizza topping option, as it balances well with the salty pizza (the dough, sauce, andn especially cheese), creating a balance of all tastes, minus unlikeable bitter.

arguments.attacks: The sweetness of the pineapple is a bad fit for the general taste of the pizza.
arguments.supports: The sweetness of the pineapple is a good fit for the general taste of the pizza.
arguments.text: The sweetness of the pineapple forms a beautiful contrast to the otherwise savory pizza.

arguments.attacks: Pineapple does not enhance the pizza-indulging experience, making pizza bring a lesser joy to and satisfaction from eating than it otherwise would.
arguments.supports: Pineapple enhances the pizza-indulging experience, making pizza bring a greater joy to and satisfaction from eating than ever before.
arguments.text: Pineapple adds a texture and mouthfeel (in between crisp and juicy) that is missing from most pizzas. Textural variety makes for a more pleasing meal.

arguments.attacks: The nature of pizza prevents pineapple from being on it.
arguments.supports: The nature of pizza does not prevent pineapple from being on it.
arguments.text: Nothing in the definition of the word 'pizza' says that pineapple should not or does not belong on it

arguments.attacks: Pineapple does not provide aesthetic tastes and taste experiences.
arguments.supports: Pineapple provides aesthetic tastes and taste experiences.
arguments.text: Pineapple have a really good taste. Even if the combination isn't perfect, the added pineapple taste still makes the pizza taste better.

arguments.attacks: Pineapple is not already part of a meal.
arguments.supports: Pineapple is already part of a meal (like in a drink or dessert). So while adding pineapple to pizza might enhance its taste, it becomes an overkill to the overall meal experience.
arguments.text: People are used to the sweet taste of the pineapple in the drink or dessert. If added to the pizza as a more savory standpoint, it may be a disappointment.

arguments.attacks: The sweetness of the pineapple is a good fit for the general taste of the pizza.
arguments.supports: The sweetness of the pineapple is a bad fit for the general taste of the pizza.
arguments.text: All that pineapple does on a pizza is disturb the harmony of all other savoury ingredients. It's such a spoilsport.

arguments.attacks: Pineapple does not provide aesthetic tastes and taste experiences.
arguments.supports: Pineapple provides aesthetic tastes and taste experiences.
arguments.text: Pineapple on pizza gives it more flavor.

userTurns.utterance: I firmly believe that mandatory organ donation is essential for improving transplant statistics and reducing unethical 'buying and selling organs', ultimately reducing wait times and increasing chances of successful transplant operations for those in need.

systemResponse.utterance: Mandatory organ donation, while seemingly beneficial, is unethical and damaging. Forcing individuals to donate infringes upon deeply held religious beliefs and personal autonomy, creating moral distress. There are also less restrictive alternatives that could increase organ availability without resorting to coercion.

response.content: Mandatory organ donation, while seemingly beneficial, is unethical and damaging. Forcing individuals to donate infringes upon deeply held religious beliefs and personal autonomy, creating moral distress. There are also less restrictive alternatives that could increase organ availability without resorting to coercion.

arguments.attacks: We should not implement mandatory organ donation until this technology is fully viable.
arguments.supports: This may well be true, but we should still implement mandatory organ donation until this technology is fully viable.
arguments.text: We should not allow the pressure on the current organ donation system build up in the off-chance that a better, more effective solution may be found in the future. Mandatory donation can ease that pressure relatively quickly.

arguments.attacks: Shortage in countries with opt-out policies is more related to compatibility/non controlled death than with non consent.
arguments.supports: Shortage in countries with opt-out policies is less related to compatibility/non controlled death than with non-consent.
arguments.text: Mandatory organ donation will decrease the shortage regardless of the total compatibility rate and save human lives.

arguments.attacks: Organ donation should be mandatory.
arguments.supports: Organ donation should not be mandatory.
arguments.text: Mandatory organ donation is unethical and damaging.

arguments.attacks: Mandatory donation will complicate the procedures after death leading to more organs being needlessly wasted.
arguments.supports: Mandatory donation will simplify the procedures after death leading to fewer organs being needlessly wasted.
arguments.text: There are many reasons people don't donate their organs or their next of kin's organs that don't involve being opposed to organ donation. Mandatory organ donation solves those instances.

arguments.attacks: Organ donation should not be mandatory.
arguments.supports: Organ donation should be mandatory.
arguments.text: Mandatory donation will simplify the procedures after death leading to fewer organs being needlessly wasted.

arguments.topic: Should we offer one of our kidneys to a stranger in need if we are able to?
arguments.attacks: If able to, a person should offer one of their kidneys up for donation to a stranger in need.
arguments.supports: If able to, a person should not offer one of their kidneys up for donation to a stranger in need.
arguments.text: An organ donation is an unreasonably demanding ethical mandate.

arguments.attacks: Mandatory organ donation does not stand counter to core tenets of many religions, and therefore does not violate religious freedom.
arguments.supports: Mandatory organ donation stands counter to core tenets of many religions, and would hence violate religious freedom.
arguments.text: Adherents of some religions may believe that the fate of their eternal soul could be compromised by mandatory organ donation. It would be grossly unfair and cruel to force them to endure this prospect for most of their lives.

arguments.attacks: Technological and scientific advances offer a possible solution.
arguments.supports: Technological and scientific advances do not offer a possible solution.
arguments.text: This may well be true, but we should still implement mandatory organ donation until this technology is fully viable.

arguments.attacks: Organ donation should be mandatory.
arguments.supports: Organ donation should not be mandatory.
arguments.text: There are alternatives to mandatory organ donation.

arguments.attacks: More organs will reduce the demand for harmful black market alternatives.
arguments.supports: More organs will increase the demand for harmful black market alternatives.
arguments.text: Voluntary sale of one's own organs would also reduce the demand for black market alternatives as well as State violence resultant from mandates.

userTurns.utterance: However, while opting-in voluntary organ donation schemes have shown to increase transplant rates, the resulting number of available organs still falls significantly short of meeting the needs of those on waiting lists, thus arguing for mandatory donation as a viable solution.

response.content: Mandatory organ donation, despite potential increases in organ availability, is ethically damaging due to religious objections and personal autonomy concerns. Less restrictive alternatives and future advancements in organ technology may address shortages without coercion.

arguments.attacks: We should not implement mandatory organ donation until this technology is fully viable.

arguments.text: We should not allow the pressure on the current organ donation system build up in the off-chance that a better, more effective solution may be found in the future. Mandatory donation can ease that pressure relatively quickly.

arguments.attacks: Shortage in countries with opt-out policies is more related to compatibility/non controlled death than with non consent.

arguments.text: Mandatory organ donation will decrease the shortage regardless of the total compatibility rate and save human lives.

userTurns.utterance: If Abolishing Privacy became a reality, society could transition towards more effective crime management and public service through data-enabled targeted solutions; allowing law enforcement stronger accountability and evidence.

systemResponse.utterance: Abolishing privacy would likely lead to an oppressive surveillance state, not a crime-free society. While some envision benefits, others argue such an invasion of privacy is an international crime itself, creating a far greater societal wrong. True societal safety requires a balance between privacy and security, not its complete elimination.

response.content: Abolishing privacy would likely lead to an oppressive surveillance state, not a crime-free society. While some envision benefits, others argue such an invasion of privacy is an international crime itself, creating a far greater societal wrong. True societal safety requires a balance between privacy and security, not its complete elimination.

arguments.attacks: This will lead to widespread discrimination against certain groups.
arguments.supports: This will not lead to widespread discrimination against certain groups.
arguments.text: Privacy is something that cannot be really achieved, this is especially true the more technology advances and pervades our lives. There are subjects that continually collect data about us, and they cannot be stopped or controlled. The more laws enforcing privacy we do the more we create a discrimination between those that can see other people privacy and those who cannot. Abolishing privacy would restore an equality on this.

arguments.attacks: Moral claims are relative to individual circumstances. Individuals are best placed to understand their own circumstances and so they â€” not society or their peers â€” are best placed to determine what is moral.
arguments.supports: Moral claims are absolute and not relative to individual circumstances. Individuals are not best placed to understand their own circumstances and so they â€” not society or their peers â€” are not best placed to determine what is moral.
arguments.text: With the elimination of privacy, society could better understand each individual's circumstances.

arguments.attacks: The world will become significantly more honest and transparent.
arguments.supports: The world will not become significantly more honest and transparent.
arguments.text: Absolutely abolishing privacy necessitates a complete honest, benevolence in society. Societies need ways to compensate for situations where the systems flaws are exploited, privacy in some cases is a good option to accomplish such end.

arguments.attacks: The act of removing all privacy is not a crime against humanity.
arguments.supports: Seeing that it is immoral to take away privacy without consent, the act of removing all privacy is itself a crime against humanity, so it cannot make society "crime free".
arguments.text: It is meaningless to say that a society will become crime free so long as it tolerates a particular sustained crime by the state. And an invasion of privacy like this is an international crime.EU Human Right to Privacy

arguments.attacks: The world would become safer and free of crime.
arguments.supports: The world would not become safer and free of crime.
arguments.text: Seeing that it is immoral to take away privacy without consent, the act of removing all privacy is itself a crime against humanity, so it cannot make society "crime free".

arguments.attacks: This will create a panoptic world where the constant possibility of shame and punishment causes people to heavily regulate their actions.
arguments.supports: This will not create a panoptic world where the constant possibility of shame and punishment causes people to heavily regulate their actions.
arguments.text: Privacy is already being severely eroded. Organizing a government-led abolition seems better than allowing us to create a world where no-one knows to what extent they have any privacy left.

arguments.attacks: The act of removing all privacy is not a crime against humanity.
arguments.supports: Seeing that it is immoral to take away privacy without consent, the act of removing all privacy is itself a crime against humanity, so it cannot make society "crime free".
arguments.text: Crime is a relative term decided by the majority. Lack of privacy will not make the world safer. Medicine would not have advanced if doctors wouldn't risk their lives by stealing corpses for research when the Catholic church made it illegal. While that was not a democracy you need to understand that the definition of crime is decided by majority and is not always a good definition. Abolishing privacy wont create a safer world ... rather a balance between privacy and security will.

arguments.attacks: The right to privacy is a natural right:Â inherent and invaluable to all humans.
arguments.supports: The right to privacy is not a natural right.
arguments.text: Privacy, without any form of accountability, will likely lead to a more isolated, anarchical, society.

arguments.topic: Should the US adopt stricter gun controls?
arguments.attacks: People do not have the right to choose their own ultimate goal.
arguments.supports: Safety is one goal, but to some, freedom is the more ultimate goal.  People have the right to choose their own ultimate goal.
arguments.text: We could almost certainly eliminate nearly all crime if we implemented oppressive universal surveillance, but we consider this to be an illegitimate invasion of privacy. This means that there is a balance between freedom and safety that society is trying to find.

arguments.attacks: The database necessarily compromises free thought or free movement; it does not just reveal our actions.
arguments.supports: The database does not necessarily compromise free thought or free movement; it just reveals our actions.
arguments.text: It isn't possible to abolish privacy entirely, as there would always be a way to conceal thoughts and actions to some degree.

topic.description: Should the age of consent be lowered to fourteen?
